final_answer.precision_note: Answer given to 3 significant figures, consistent with the precision of the NaOH concentration (0.150 mol dm-3) and volumes (25.00 cm3 and 23.40 cm3).

method: First convert volumes to dm3: V(NaOH) = 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3, V(H2SO4) = 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Calculate moles of NaOH using c = n/V rearranged to n = cV: n(NaOH) = 0.150 mol dm-3 x 0.02340 dm3 = 0.003510 mol. From the balanced equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O, the mole ratio is 1:2, so n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH)/2 = 0.003510/2 = 0.001755 mol. Finally, calculate concentration: c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Moles of NaOH = 0.150 x 0.02340 = 0.003510 mol is correctly halved for the 1:2 ratio to give moles of H2SO4.
Concentration = 0.001755 mol / 0.02500 dm3 = 0.0702 mol dm-3 confirms the calculation.
